descriptionModule.briefSummary: To determine the safety and efficacy of in situ ischemic postconditioning immediately after successful reperfusion in AIS patients underwnet EVT.
descriptionModule.detailedDescription: For acute ischemic stroke (AIS) patients with large vessel occlusion in the anterior circulation receieved successful reperfusion, in situ ischemic postconditioning (ISIPC) was performed immediately after successful reperfusion with 5 circules of balloon inflations in the ipsilateral internal carotid artery, each circulation includes inflation lasting 15 seconds followed by 15 seconds of deflation.

bioSpec.description: thrombus retrieved from the occluded artery. Serum collected from the vein at different time points.

armGroups.label: rapid local ischemic postconditioning (RL-IPostC) group
armGroups.description: RL-IPostC is performed immediately after successful reperfusion with 5 circules of balloon inflations in the ipsilateral internal carotid artery, each circulation includes inflation lasting 15 seconds followed by 15 seconds of deflation.

armGroups.label: control group
armGroups.description: no intervention was provided after successful reperfusion

interventions.name: rapid local ischemic postconditioning (RL-IPostC)
interventions.description: with 5 circules of balloon inflations in the ipsilateral internal carotid artery, each circulation includes inflation lasting 15 seconds followed by 15 seconds of deflation

secondaryOutcomes.description: defined as a decrease in the NIHSS score of ≥10 from baseline or an NIHSS score of 0 or 1
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: on day 5, 6, or 7 of hospitalization or at discharge if it occurred before day 5

secondaryOutcomes.description: Mortality of 3 month after stoke onset
according to European Cooperative Acute Stroke Study II criteria
an increase of ≥4 points on the National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale (NIHSS) according to Heidelberg Bleeding Classification

defined as infarct lesions with significant space-occupying mass effect with over 1/2 affected middle cerebral artery territory with imaging signs of herniation and/or and clinical signs of herniation requiring decompressive hemicraniectomy and/or leading to death due to direct implications of stroke

eligibilityModule.studyPopulation: Patients were treated according to national guidelines for treatment of AIS, including intravenous thrombolysis, if indicated. Thrombectomy were performed according to standard techniques. The method of endovascular therapy was selected at the discretion of treating physicians and could include stent retriever and/or catheter aspiration.
